<issue_start><issue_comment>Title: feat: Update Vercel banner in footer
username_0: Things added/changed:

- Update Vercel banner in the footer.

[![Powered by Vercel](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/TheAlgorithms/website/b6359713f530afd302232dd57069a85981bf994a/public/powered-by-vercel.svg)](https://vercel.com?utm_source=thealgorithms&utm_campaign=oss)

<issue_comment>username_0: Not sure why the Vercel checks haven't run yet...Weird.
Anyways I have added this repository in the [Vercel](https://vercel.com/thealgorithms/website/settings/git) settings.

Hope that works. ðŸ™‚
<issue_comment>username_1: Have you done that before or after opening the pr?
<issue_comment>username_1: Here's a manual preview deployment of the pr https://website-jdwqy697s-thealgorithms.vercel.app/

I've also put in this badge at first, but I think the white text fits more in with the page. What do you think looks better?
<issue_comment>username_0: For me, the one in the first comment looks better than the other one. ðŸ™‚

<issue_start><issue_comment>Title: Sponsor needed for snacks on Saturday
username_0: ## Why Snacks?

The night before was a party. If the attendees don't need a snack now, they must have some other secret sauce to get their bodies back up to speed. But many rely on a sponsor to help out and prevent a low blood sugar by providing quick energy refilling snacks in the form of sweets, baked goods and candy. Keep those hard working brains happy - either by choosing yourself what to get or just leave it up to us to find the right sugar-bombs!

## How does it work?

Last year we asked some food companies for offers and had the sponsor confirm that amount up front. Once the food was delivered on the day the sponsor pulled out the credit card and made all attendees happy by enabling them to making the blood sugar level catch up.
<issue_comment>username_1: Hey Marco,
we are a Start-Up from Augsburg and want to ensure the blood sugar supply for the attendees of the JSCraftCamp.
Please [get in touch with me](mailto:r.koch@cioplenu.de) to steer the sponsoring properly
<issue_comment>username_2: Awesome! Thanks for sponsoring the JSCraftCamp.
Oh that sounds cool. Can you please give us a link to your company name and logo, so we can put it on the website.
<issue_comment>username_1: Sure @username_2 . You can find out more about cioplenu under https://cioplenu.com/. Logo files for the website can be found [here](https://cloud.sicony.de/s/y42TBWGnfcMZY5d)<issue_closed>
<issue_comment>username_2: sponsor found, the next steps are handled in 
https://github.com/jscraftcamp/website/issues/498 by the JSCC crew. thanks

<issue_start><issue_comment>Title: Blogger import doesn't seem to work
username_0: I'm trying to migrate from a blogger blog to a nikola-powered site, but I'm running into problems. I'm trying the following:

$ nikola init foo
Created empty site at foo.

$ cd foo/

$ nikola import_blogger ~/Downloads/code/blog-03-21-2013.xml

<issue_start><issue_comment>Title: Missing documentation for UIManager
username_0: I was trying to find out how to use a [`PopupMenu`][1] with RN. While browsing the documentation, I found no mention of how this would be possible without an external plugin. I jumped to searching in Google and found a small snippet, in a comment of [#3004][2] of react-native's git, referring to `UIManager` and its `showPopupMenu` API. I believe this is a powerful native feature of which documentation shall be not only in the [source code][3], but also in the docs website.

[1]: https://developer.android.com/reference/android/widget/PopupMenu
[2]: https://github.com/facebook/react-native/issues/3004#issuecomment-202598006
[3]: https://github.com/facebook/react-native/blob/39b68903463062f69c9120fab7e79fa2735b0b07/ReactAndroid/src/main/java/com/facebook/react/uimanager/NativeViewHierarchyManager.java#LC777
<issue_comment>username_1: Iâ€™m happy to write this up, at least for iOS. I havenâ€™t gotten to the Android port yet. Should this be a separate document or part of one of the existing ones?
<issue_comment>username_0: Acually `Popup Menu` is only applicable in Android.
<issue_comment>username_2: These remain missing. 

The 3rd-party typescript definitions have descriptions and type signatures for many of the `UIManager` methods:

https://github.com/DefinitelyTyped/DefinitelyTyped/blob/da93d7b13094bacb170ead3f4a289f3b8687e4e5/types/react-native/index.d.ts#L8001

But it's still missing some methods, like [`.viewIsDescendantOf`](https://github.com/facebook/react-native/blob/fb627dac6a03f4ab52def4375812fbaf4804dcac/Libraries/ReactNative/NativeUIManager.js#L62).
<issue_comment>username_0: Searching for `showPopupMenu` still yields no results in the documentation site.

[{'action': 'opened', 'author': 'Cobra-Bitcoin', 'comment_id': None, 'datetime': '2020-08-23T00:10:18Z', 'masked_author': 'username_0', 'text': 'Hey guys, I've been working on a new desktop Bitcoin wallet the past month that defaults to P2SH wrapped Segwit out of the box and is basically orientated to be very noob friendly. So far almost all of the code is complete, with the only things left being to add some tests, get the strings translated, and have a professional designer improve the look and feel (I'm not really good at design so it looks kind of... minimal?). The code is in Typescript and it uses Vue.js as the Javascript framework. It's built for Electron, so it'll be able to ship to Windows, Mac and Linux easily.

I've been pretty unhappy with the desktop wallet offerings for a while now, I feel like they all do "too much" in some way or another, or they're re-hashed versions of existing mobile wallets like the BitPay wallet. My goal with this wallet is to create something that doesn't support _every_ feature under the sun, is well designed, built and aimed for desktop, and has a strong focus on internationalization (currently the Spanish translations are just Google translated, so don't judge too harshly, though I want to have support for at least 5 languages at launch, and keep adding as many as we can, luckily we already have a really good translation team that can help out).

The wallet backend is powered by our own ElectrumX servers. The user gets the standard 12 word seed phrase to keep secure, and it works like most HD wallets in that used external addresses are never shown again. There's no custom fee selection, because newbies shouldn't be setting their own fees, instead there's only 3 options for fee level that they can select from (low priority, standard, and important). It can also handle various international number formats, so a user in England can type in to send 'Â£20.5' and a German user can type in 'â‚¬20,5' and both will display the correct BTC amount when they're trying to send. There will never be support for Multi-sig, RBF, custom UTXO selection, watch-only addresses, and all that other stuff that most people don't actually need.

All the development is open source and you can follow along here: https://github.com/bitcoin-dot-org/Bitcoin-Wallet. Ultimately my philosophy with this wallet is _**removing**_ features, or at worst, adding features but doing it invisibly. For example if we want to add Lightning in the future one day, it would have to be done in a way such that the user doesn't have to know _anything_ about Lightning and can just keep using the wallet the same way without altering their behavior. Right now I'm the only one working on the wallet, but some outside contributions would be appreciated, especially in helping me write a good test suite.', 'title': 'A noob friendly desktop Segwit (BIP-49) Bitcoin Wallet', 'type': 'issue'}
 {'action': 'created', 'author': 'cryptohakka', 'comment_id': 679229859.0, 'datetime': '2020-08-24 16:23:31+00:00', 'masked_author': 'username_1', 'text': '@username_0 
Thanks! Beginners will need simple wallet as you say. They don't need complicated features. 
Your thought about Japanese currency symbol is almost correct.
"ä¸‡" means ten thousands. "å††" means Yen and this is Japanese currency symbol.
10,000 Yen and 100,000 Yen are expressed in Japanese as follows.
　10,000 Yen = 1ä¸‡å††
　100,000 Yen = 10ä¸‡å††', 'title': None, 'type': 'comment'}
 {'action': 'created', 'author': 'Cobra-Bitcoin', 'comment_id': 687298477.0, 'datetime': '2020-09-04 18:00:29+00:00', 'masked_author': 'username_0', 'text': "Good news, we're getting professional design work done to improve the wallet, which will start next week.

While that's being done, I'm going to set up some ElectrumX servers and put them behind a load balancer, since right now everything is running off of just one ElectrumX server.", 'title': None, 'type': 'comment'}
 {'action': 'created', 'author': 'pavlenex', 'comment_id': 711027516.0, 'datetime': '2020-10-17 15:13:11+00:00', 'masked_author': 'username_2', 'text': "@username_0 Do you plan to add the strings on Transifex? What's a preferred way to submit translated strings? A PR to `src/lang/`?", 'title': None, 'type': 'comment'}
 {'action': 'created', 'author': 'Cobra-Bitcoin', 'comment_id': 711032846.0, 'datetime': '2020-10-17 15:46:50+00:00', 'masked_author': 'username_0', 'text': "@username_2 Yeah, it will be added to Transifex.

For now it's easier to do it as a PR, but keep in mind that although 80% of the strings will stay the same, there will be some change in the next week of parts of the text, so it's better to wait after that, so the text can be translated correctly all at once.", 'title': None, 'type': 'comment'}
 {'action': 'created', 'author': 'Cobra-Bitcoin', 'comment_id': 763433016.0, 'datetime': '2021-01-20 08:37:29+00:00', 'masked_author': 'username_0', 'text': "Just to update:

The [mobile version](https://github.com/bitcoin-dot-org/BitcoinWalletMobile.) will go into the app stores shortly.  From there we need to verify it's actually safe, so unfortunately, before we have it up on bitcoin.org, the people who discover it on the app store by themselves are the guinea pigs. Once it's on the stores, let's keep it lowkey, we don't want too many people running this until it's rock solid. Since the desktop version uses the same wallet code, once the mobile wallet is confirmed solid, we'll know it's OK too.

It won't skip past the normal review process for a wallet that gets listed on bitcoin.org, and I'm looking forward to @crwatkins grilling it.", 'title': None, 'type': 'comment'}]
column6:
<issue_start><issue_comment>Title: A noob friendly desktop Segwit (BIP-49) Bitcoin Wallet
username_0: Hey guys, I've been working on a new desktop Bitcoin wallet the past month that defaults to P2SH wrapped Segwit out of the box and is basically orientated to be very noob friendly. So far almost all of the code is complete, with the only things left being to add some tests, get the strings translated, and have a professional designer improve the look and feel (I'm not really good at design so it looks kind of... minimal?). The code is in Typescript and it uses Vue.js as the Javascript framework. It's built for Electron, so it'll be able to ship to Windows, Mac and Linux easily.

I've been pretty unhappy with the desktop wallet offerings for a while now, I feel like they all do "too much" in some way or another, or they're re-hashed versions of existing mobile wallets like the BitPay wallet. My goal with this wallet is to create something that doesn't support _every_ feature under the sun, is well designed, built and aimed for desktop, and has a strong focus on internationalization (currently the Spanish translations are just Google translated, so don't judge too harshly, though I want to have support for at least 5 languages at launch, and keep adding as many as we can, luckily we already have a really good translation team that can help out).

The wallet backend is powered by our own ElectrumX servers. The user gets the standard 12 word seed phrase to keep secure, and it works like most HD wallets in that used external addresses are never shown again. There's no custom fee selection, because newbies shouldn't be setting their own fees, instead there's only 3 options for fee level that they can select from (low priority, standard, and important). It can also handle various international number formats, so a user in England can type in to send 'Â£20.5' and a German user can type in 'â‚¬20,5' and both will display the correct BTC amount when they're trying to send. There will never be support for Multi-sig, RBF, custom UTXO selection, watch-only addresses, and all that other stuff that most people don't actually need.

All the development is open source and you can follow along here: https://github.com/bitcoin-dot-org/Bitcoin-Wallet. Ultimately my philosophy with this wallet is _**removing**_ features, or at worst, adding features but doing it invisibly. For example if we want to add Lightning in the future one day, it would have to be done in a way such that the user doesn't have to know _anything_ about Lightning and can just keep using the wallet the same way without altering their behavior. Right now I'm the only one working on the wallet, but some outside contributions would be appreciated, especially in helping me write a good test suite.
<issue_comment>username_1: @username_0 
Thanks! Beginners will need simple wallet as you say. They don't need complicated features. 
Your thought about Japanese currency symbol is almost correct.
"ä¸‡" means ten thousands. "å††" means Yen and this is Japanese currency symbol.
10,000 Yen and 100,000 Yen are expressed in Japanese as follows.
ã€€10,000 Yen = 1ä¸‡å††
ã€€100,000 Yen = 10ä¸‡å††
<issue_comment>username_0: Good news, we're getting professional design work done to improve the wallet, which will start next week.

While that's being done, I'm going to set up some ElectrumX servers and put them behind a load balancer, since right now everything is running off of just one ElectrumX server.
<issue_comment>username_2: @username_0 Do you plan to add the strings on Transifex? What's a preferred way to submit translated strings? A PR to `src/lang/`?
<issue_comment>username_0: @username_2 Yeah, it will be added to Transifex.

For now it's easier to do it as a PR, but keep in mind that although 80% of the strings will stay the same, there will be some change in the next week of parts of the text, so it's better to wait after that, so the text can be translated correctly all at once.
<issue_comment>username_0: Just to update:

The [mobile version](https://github.com/bitcoin-dot-org/BitcoinWalletMobile.) will go into the app stores shortly.  From there we need to verify it's actually safe, so unfortunately, before we have it up on bitcoin.org, the people who discover it on the app store by themselves are the guinea pigs. Once it's on the stores, let's keep it lowkey, we don't want too many people running this until it's rock solid. Since the desktop version uses the same wallet code, once the mobile wallet is confirmed solid, we'll know it's OK too.

It won't skip past the normal review process for a wallet that gets listed on bitcoin.org, and I'm looking forward to @crwatkins grilling it.

column5:
[{'action': 'opened', 'author': 'PhilipMay', 'comment_id': None, 'datetime': '2021-12-13 11:25:29+00:00', 'masked_author': 'username_0', 'text': 'I have a "bare metal" Debian 11 server and install k8s with kubeadm.

I follow this guide: https://kubernetes.io/docs/setup/production-environment/tools/kubeadm/create-cluster-kubeadm/

The install with `kubeadm init --pod-network-cidr=192.168.0.0/16` fails:

```text
[wait-control-plane] Waiting for the kubelet to boot up the control plane as static Pods from directory "/etc/kubernetes/manifests". This can take up to 4m0s
[kubelet-check] Initial timeout of 40s passed.

	Unfortunately, an error has occurred:
		timed out waiting for the condition

	This error is likely caused by:
		- The kubelet is not running
		- The kubelet is unhealthy due to a misconfiguration of the node in some way (required cgroups disabled)

	If you are on a systemd-powered system, you can try to troubleshoot the error with the following commands:
		- 'systemctl status kubelet'
		- 'journalctl -xeu kubelet'

	Additionally, a control plane component may have crashed or exited when started by the container runtime.
	To troubleshoot, list all containers using your preferred container runtimes CLI.

	Here is one example how you may list all Kubernetes containers running in cri-o/containerd using crictl:
		- 'crictl --runtime-endpoint /run/containerd/containerd.sock ps -a | grep kube | grep -v pause'
		Once you have found the failing container, you can inspect its logs with:
		- 'crictl --runtime-endpoint /run/containerd/containerd.sock logs CONTAINERID'

error execution phase wait-control-plane: couldn't initialize a Kubernetes cluster
To see the stack trace of this error execute with --v=5 or higher
```

Looking at containerd logs shows this: `error="failed to create containerd container: get apparmor_parser version: exec: \"apparmor_parser\": executable file not found in $PATH"`

Installing apparmor `apt install apparmor` fixes it and the installation works.

IMO this dependency should be added at the installation instructions. Somehere here: https://kubernetes.io/docs/setup/production-environment/tools/kubeadm/create-cluster-kubeadm/', 'title': 'kubeadm install needs apparmor', 'type': 'issue'}

<issue_start><issue_comment>Title: kubeadm install needs apparmor
username_0: I have a "bare metal" Debian 11 server and install k8s with kubeadm.

I follow this guide: https://kubernetes.io/docs/setup/production-environment/tools/kubeadm/create-cluster-kubeadm/

The install with `kubeadm init --pod-network-cidr=192.168.0.0/16` fails:

```text
[wait-control-plane] Waiting for the kubelet to boot up the control plane as static Pods from directory "/etc/kubernetes/manifests". This can take up to 4m0s
[kubelet-check] Initial timeout of 40s passed.

	Unfortunately, an error has occurred:
		timed out waiting for the condition

	This error is likely caused by:
		- The kubelet is not running
		- The kubelet is unhealthy due to a misconfiguration of the node in some way (required cgroups disabled)

	If you are on a systemd-powered system, you can try to troubleshoot the error with the following commands:
		- 'systemctl status kubelet'
		- 'journalctl -xeu kubelet'

	Additionally, a control plane component may have crashed or exited when started by the container runtime.
	To troubleshoot, list all containers using your preferred container runtimes CLI.

	Here is one example how you may list all Kubernetes containers running in cri-o/containerd using crictl:
		- 'crictl --runtime-endpoint /run/containerd/containerd.sock ps -a | grep kube | grep -v pause'
		Once you have found the failing container, you can inspect its logs with:
		- 'crictl --runtime-endpoint /run/containerd/containerd.sock logs CONTAINERID'

error execution phase wait-control-plane: couldn't initialize a Kubernetes cluster
To see the stack trace of this error execute with --v=5 or higher
```

Looking at containerd logs shows this: `error="failed to create containerd container: get apparmor_parser version: exec: \"apparmor_parser\": executable file not found in $PATH"`

Installing apparmor `apt install apparmor` fixes it and the installation works.

IMO this dependency should be added at the installation instructions. Somehere here: https://kubernetes.io/docs/setup/production-environment/tools/kubeadm/create-cluster-kubeadm/
<issue_comment>username_1: /sig cluster-lifecycle
/language en
<issue_comment>username_0: Well - it could be added as a hint in this "Install containerd:" box here: https://kubernetes.io/docs/setup/production-environment/container-runtimes/#containerd

Want me to suggest a PR?
<issue_comment>username_2: I am waiting on a response in
https://github.com/kubernetes/kubernetes/issues/106974 from sig node
because apparmor was not a requirement before.

Maybe containerd changed.

/sig node
<issue_comment>username_1: /priority awaiting-more-evidence
<issue_comment>username_1: Some docs somewhere need to change. Right now it's not clear which.
<issue_comment>username_2: response here:
https://github.com/kubernetes/kubernetes/issues/106974#issuecomment-995128016

the summary is that this is a problem (missing dependency) in the containerd packages, not the k8s packages.
please report this to containerd.

the docs in the k8s website can be updated if needed (e.g. switching to a different repo from the one from docker for containerd), but i don't think we need to mention the apparmor CLI explicitly.
<issue_comment>username_1: /remove-priority awaiting-more-evidence
/language en
/triage accepted
/priority backlog

We should update our docs on installing containerd. Perhaps we can link to external install instructions?
<issue_comment>username_2: looks like this is being updated as part of https://github.com/kubernetes/website/pull/30882/files#r805354269
https://github.com/kubernetes/website/pull/30882/files#r805354518

/close
